Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Political Economy and Policy with Imperfect Information

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research has three projects. The first studies a novel model of political economy for a small open economy. The model incorporates a main political friction (disagreement about the timing of expenditures) together with lack of commitment to tax policy or debt repayment. It is a parsimonious modification to the standard small open economy model and delivers rich dynamics driven mainly by the political economy friction. The model is thus capable of generating new and interesting predictions regarding the behavior of debt, growth and political institutions. Several important theoretical extensions and an analysis of the role of policies such as debt relief and aid are planned for future work. The second project relates to the design of optimal policy under private information. This project will extend previous economic techniques to be able to solve policy design questions when the policy maker has biased preferences but posses valuable private information. I will analyze two particular cases: (i) the optimality of budget-balance rules for fiscal authorities, and (ii) the optimality of tariff caps in trade agreements. Finally, the third project will use a recently developed macroeconomic model of information and monetary policy, to study the question of optimal public communication by a Central Bank.

Broader Impact:

The research project contributes to the economic growth literature by introducing political economy considerations into the basic toolkit of macroeconomists. It also deals with more specific policy questions that have been at the top of the agenda of several international organizations. For example, there is a large discussion regarding the role of debt relief to emerging markets, as well as an ongoing debate on the benefits (if any) of foreign aid to poor nations. The research will provide a modern framework to analyze the role of such policies. The project on balanced budget rules has important implications for policy, not only for emerging markets but also in the developed world. The project on optimal tariff rules has implications for how negotiations in GATT/WTO can be improved to benefit all parties involved. Finally, the project on communication is motivated by practical issues faced by the Federal Reserve and other Central Banks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by the grant generated several new results and publications.

1. A fundamental feature of the GATT/WTO trade negotiations is the use of tariff bindings, or tariff caps rather than precise tariff rates. Many countries negotiate for caps that lie above their current tariff levels, guaranteeing them the flexibility to raise tariffs in the future. I study the optimality of such tariff bindings, and show that they are the best tool to restrict trade (under some conditions) when transfers across countries are restricted or limited (as they are under the WTO). My contribution here is also methodological, as these results apply not only in the international trade case, but also to the more general theory of delegation. This theory deals with settings where a principal delegates a decision to an agent who is better informed about the best course of action. This theory has several different economic applications (shareholders vs managers, politicians vs population, etc). My work provides conditions under which simple delegation contracts are optimal. A paper collecting these results was published in the academic journal Econometrica.

2. The European debt crisis has focused attention on how fiscal problems can trigger self-fulfilling debt crises in countries who lack their own monetary policy, or are part of a monetary union. I show that in the context of a monetary union, a fiscal externality generally arises, as individual members of the union do not take into account the impact of their borrowing on the monetary policy of the union as a whole. Members tend to borrow too much. However, the imposition of a borrowing limit can alleviate this problem. In addition, the composition of debt within a monetary union impacts its vulnerability to self-fulfilling debt crises: a union is less vulnerable if it contains is a mix of high and low-debt members. These results were published in the Quarterly Journal of Economics, and the American Economic Association Papers and Proceedings.

3. The European debt crisis also highlights the importance of studying fiscal environments where both the government and/or its citizens face limits on external borrowing. I study optimal fiscal policy in an open economy that faces a low world interest rate. The government, and its citizens, desire to borrow but are limited by the possibility of a future default. I show that the optimal policy in this case is characterized by a tax on labor that is eventually reduced to zero. To be able to fund future expenditures, the government needs to accumulate assets (that is, run budget surpluses), and in this way, lean against the external borrowing made by other domestic agents. These results were published in the Journal of Economic Theory.

4. Another question of interest is how to design the maturity structure of government debt. I provide a new result for cases where the government operates under a significant probability of default on its bonds. I show that in this situation, it is optimal for new government debt issuances to be short-term rather than long. The results holds independently of the path of government debt, and the evolution of default probabilities. I show that the yield curve (which can be thought of as an average of default probabilities over time) is not a key determinant of the cost of borrowing -- even though it is usually thought as an important component. This is because what is important is not the yield curve, but the marginal yield curve: that is, how bond prices at different maturity react to additional issuances. These results were collected in a paper which is now undergoing the peer-review process towards publication.

5. There are several additional results from this research program. For example, by way of analytical examples, I demonstrate the existence of multiplicity of equilibria in quantitative models of sovereign debt. This has implications for how to deal with sovereign debt crisis. I also study how a Central Bank should manage its foreign reserves, when operating at close to zero interest rates under limited capital mobility. I show that, for a relatively open economy, a Central Bank just needs to guarantee that foreign investors are willing to holds its liabilities at the margin. I also analyzed the best way to regulate a monopolist without transfers;  and used a model of reputation and sovereign debt to study how countries can eventually graduate from being considered serial defaulters. These results were collected in several working papers.

6. The research supported by the grant was disseminated by (i) seminar presentations in many universities and research institutes around the US, and Europe; (ii) presentation in economics conferences, attended by academic and researchers; (iii) publication in top economic journals; (iv) circulation in working paper series; and (v) invited lectures. Several graduate students in economics were participants and contributors to research supported by the grant.
